answers.answer: Kevtt,Thanks for the post.There are no good alternatives yet.  An oral thrombin inhibitor may be available in the next 6 to 24 months, but this medication will require twice daily dosing.  The best idea would be to take the warfarin, provided there are no contraindications.Hope that helps.
My mother has recently been diagnosed with multiple strokes, she cannot take asprin because of stomach problems however she is having no problems taking Plavix.Best Wishes

What about an ulcer medication?  My 81 year old mother has A-fib, high bp, asthma and a former bleeding ulcer.  She was on Aciphex for almost a year but was switched to omeprazole for insurance reasons.  She has had no trouble with her stomach since being on these meds.

We now know my heart has tendency to go into A-Fib.  The doctors have put me on Coumadin and Cordarone.  I am diabetic, have blood pressure under control, and have diabetic neuropathy and am slowly using the use of my legs.  I am 77 years old and have had many things wrong with me over the years.  The neuropathy is the hardest for me to deal with up until now that I am on a coumadin regimin.  Anyone with this neuropathy or on Coumadin, have you some encouraging words for me?  My diabetes is under control and is not any problem.

My 45 year old husband just started taking coumadin due to a mechanical valve.  Everytime he takes it he gets a really bad headache and starts seeing a black spot in one eye.  His CAT scan shows normal.  We can't seem to get his coumadin level to 2.5.  Can anyone give me some advice?

question: An 82 year old male diagnosed with afib does not want to take coumadin (he had an acquaintance die from bleeding while on coumadin) and can't take aspirin because of past ulcer problems. Does he have other alternatives? Thank you!
title: No Coumandin or Aspirin
